displayed_text: Patient: What’s the number? Doctor: Excellent. Healthcare Professional: Can you repeat that again? I’m sorry. Family Member: Hum? Healthcare Professional: Can you repeat that? Family Member: Yes. (Patient gives phone number.) Healthcare Professional: Okay. Doctor: Beautiful. Okay. Need any refills on anything? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. So hang on and watch out for the uh yeah uh the diet and we’ll see you back in six weeks. Piece of cake. Patient: Six weeks? Doctor: Sure. Is that legit? Are you going to behave for six weeks?

Patient: It paralyzes or something. I don’t like that feeling. Doctor: Yeah. No, I don’t want to wait until you get paralyzed either. Patient: It would be in my arms. Doctor: Right. Patient: It would be in my arms and my feet, my toes. Doctor: Yeah, because, but we don’t want to wait until you know it totally messes up with your… Doctor: …walking and stuff. Patient: It’s coming a long… Doctor: Yeah, yeah, but the cancer has stayed in check for a really long time with the chemo… Patient: Okay. Doctor: …so I think uh so far the chemo has done you good. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Alright. So today we’ll go ahead and I know you gave G____ the list of medications…

Patient: Yeah. Could we do it Thursday afternoon? Doctor: Sure, yeah. Family Member: It’s just an echo… Patient: How long does it take – to do that ? Doctor: It’s about, not a very long time, but it would mean that I would just need to, we would need to coordinate the echo appointment and all that- that’s why I’m just asking you for Patient: Thursday afternoon. Doctor: -a few days. that work out well for you Because… Patient: Thursday afternoon. We’re going to Canada on Saturday morning. Doctor: Okay and then next week. Patient: Closer than Vancouver. Doctor: Fair enough. Next week anytime? Family Member: For the same thing?

Patient: No, I don’t think so. Doctor: Well then next time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh the, I don’t know if they come back yet. I saw that… Patient: And I had a bone density done . And I sent that to her, I don’t know if you saw that? Doctor: Uh and G___ is what kind of doctor? Patient: Uh he’s my oncologist Patient: I’m presuming no. where I uh had the scans done Doctor: I’ll ask about it. My sense is don’t order a lot of those tests because Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: If you not having any bone or physical symptoms If it meets the threshold, they can give you a pill Patient: Yeah, yeah, at the same time, so

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.disagree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::disagree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Homemaker: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Homemaker

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: Uh I have to tell Dr. C____, but I’m gonna go for it. Doctor: Okay. Yeah. Patient: I need to make an appointment with him and do the uh. Doctor: For the scope and all that. Patient: Scope. Doctor: So he makes sure the passage is okay and the bladder is safe and all that. Alright so I’ll let them know if you’re okay with it. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Okay and uh then we’ll plan for your appointment after the cryo and everything is done. So forget about the June appointment. We’ll just schedule something later on. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay because probably the whole month of June will be taken up so most likely it will be somewhere end of July or so. Okay? Patient: So how do I make the appointment for the scope? Doctor: Yeah I’m gonna tell them so the scheduler will hook you up or J the nurse will talk to the scheduler. Patient: Okay.

Patient: All of whom. All of whom. All eight, including the, the black guy who did this study from Harvard, were convinced that they had Native American, uh, genes. None. (Laughs) Doctor: Well, you know, I, I did this myself. Ancest--I did Ancestry. Patient: Yeah. I might do that. Doctor: And, uh, I don’t know what they. I don’t know enough about what they use as a marker to say you’re --- Patient: Yeah, x-y-or z. Doctor: I want to say, I think Native American, there’s certain mutations that might come up that are only in Native American population. So, anyway, my, my story was my, my name is D_. My, there’s a town in England called D_. I had done my genealogy back to eighteen twenty. Until, you know, my --- two generations ago came to America, multiple generations lived in England. Patient: Do you know that for sure? Doctor: Were married to people in England, had children in England. So, I’m English, right? And, then, my moth --- my grandmother’s German. My grandfather is English. So I’m going to do my Ancestry.com just to confirm, um, you know, those are my things. Family Member: I betcha you’re German, like us, yeah. Doctor: No English. I don’t even know how it’s possible because Doctor: It came back, like, I was German. My mother is Italian. That was there. The German was there, but it didn’t even mention English. And then, there was a little note, saying, “A low probability, four percent, English.” Like, no, that’s impossible because, English, English, English, English. Doctor: I see all of this, and I’m like, hmmm, I wonder if one of my great grandfathers is not English. (Laughs) Patient: He might have been a Norman.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: The computer makes the decision as to whether you get the extra drug or not. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And there always is the possibility that when you go through some of this checking, you’re not eligible. Patient: Um. Doctor: Okay, I think we have ninety days from when you got your first shot, which was November six or seven – Patient: Um hum. Doctor: to get things going. And so that’s why I put this appointment on the books. So let’s get the hormones started. You know you will say, “I want it; I don’t want it; I do want it.” In other words I’m not trying to put, you know but we have to have and then your opinion back. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So we weren’t making any decisions. So I’m delighted today that you feel better, that you can’t complain of anything. Patient: Right. Doctor: Your creatinine is down at one. And then if you’re still interested, then we would go for it. If you say, “I’m not interested”, if you’re not interested then you have to think about when do we start you know the chemotherapy. And that’s what we would probably do anyway. If you go through the process about the trial and they say you’re not eligible, then we would give the chemo anyway. Patient: Yeah anyway.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: The new one and then the OxyContin and then uh your Percocet. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now what’s going on with your Zometa and everything? That’s XGEVA is B___ doing that? Patient: Yeah, yes they are, yes they are. Doctor: Alright. Patient: Because you gave the thing last time on on on my uh calcium. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: They highered my calcium level now. Doctor: Let’s see what is this guys’ intake? Yeah it was too low last time.

Patient: That’s a different study. Doctor: Because that only works against the bone. Patient: Oh. Doctor: So unless I see and okay the bone scan, I was just looking, they did they compared it to a two-thousand-fourteen bone scan. So I really cannot tell too much. The only new findings are really this one on your bone scan – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: and that we are very well aware about that we know. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So those were there even before you started the Xofigo. Patient: Right. Doctor: The radiation. Patient: Right. Doctor: So right now I think we will be in just watch and wait mode because I see no recompelling reason to put you on a new treatment.

Patient: The Erlida? Doctor: The Erlida, yeah. Patient: Two weeks ago I think. Doctor: Two weeks. Okay. Patient: Well, let's see now. Family Member 1: When you came last week? No? Patient: No, I think was the week before and you told me to stop. Doctor: Yeah. Right. Right. I think it's been at least two weeks. Patient: Yeah, at least two weeks. Doctor: Hopefully, it'll you know, flush out some more slowly get better. You know, the more natural thing you should ask her. She's gonna be the expert, you know, like melatonin. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Things like that. Family Member 1: He does try them.
